NEWS BITES

Experts Believe India’s New Housing Sector Package Falls Short This weekend, India’s Finance Minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, unveiled a housing sector package meant to boost the industry, but experts don’t believe it offers enough support to address the issues of low demand and slow sales needed to achieve the prime minister’s goal of housing for all in 2020. The Hindu Business Line

The Tech Industry Moves Out of Silicon Valley Into More Affordable Cities As prices continue to rise in the big tech industry centers in San Francisco, San Jose and Silicon Valley, California, techies are opting to move to smaller hubs that offer good jobs and more affordable real estate, according to realtor.com. The top three metropolitan areas with affordable median housing and strong tech industries include Huntsville, Alabama, Dallas, Texas, and Baltimore, Maryland. realtor.com

Millennials Borrowing from Retirement Accounts to Fund First Homes Millennials in their 20s and 30s are forced to be creative in collecting down payment money and are more likely than older generations to use retirement savings to do so, according to a new Bankrate survey. Millennials are also more likely than any other generation to move in with family, sell personal items and utilize down-payment assistance programs in order to afford home-buying costs. MarketWatch

Almost 800,000 Western U.S. Homes at Risk for Wildfire Damage This Year In 2018, 8.7 million acres of land were burned by wildfires, which is the sixth-highest total since the mid-1900s, according to CoreLogic’s recent Wildfire Risk Hazard Report. This year, an estimated 776,000 homes valued at $221 billion are at extreme risk of wildfire damage, especially in Los Angeles, San Diego and Riverside, California. World Property Journal

As the Australian Property Market Gains Strength, Economy Remains Sluggish Rising home prices across Australia and low interest rates are causing Australians to tighten their wallets in order to save for a home, which is hurting the rest of the economy, said Australian business owner Michael Jiang. Analysts expect two additional rate cuts to 0.5% by 2020 as Prime Minister Scott Morrison’s goal is to return to a surplus this year. South China Morning Post
